duck: Nil ideal - In mathematics, more specifically ring theory, a left, right or two-sided ideal of a ring is said to be a nil ideal if each of its elements is nilpotent.
Nilpotent group - In mathematics, more specifically in the field of group theory, a nilpotent group is a group that is "almost abelian".
Reduced ring - In ring theory, a ring R is called a reduced ring if it has no non-zero nilpotent elements.
nilpotent definition: equal to zero when raised to some power.
Nilpotent ideal - In mathematics, more specifically ring theory, an ideal, I, of a ring is said to be a nilpotent ideal, if there exists a natural number k such that Ik = 0.
Unipotent - In mathematics, a unipotent element r of a ring R is one such that r − 1 is a nilpotent element, in other words such that some powern is zero.
In mathematics, an element x of a ring R is called nilpotent if there exists some positive integer n such that x<sup>n</sup> = 0.
Idempotent element - Idempotence is the property of certain operations in mathematics and computer science, that they can be applied multiple times without changing the result.

wiki.text:
In mathematics, an element x of a ring R is called 'nilpotent' if there exists
some positive integer n such that x<sup>n</sup> = 0.

The term was introduced by Benjamin Peirce<ref>Polcino & Sehgal (2002), p.
127.</ref> in the context of elements of an algebra that vanish when raised
to a power.
wiki.title: nilpotent
